title: 110_hr3820
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Motor Vehicle Advanced Safety Technology Tax Act of 2007". Congress finds that commercial motor vehicle crashes are a major concern in the United States, especially with the increasing number of trucks and their role in transporting hazardous materials. A 2004 report shows that large truck crashes are 2.6 times more likely to result in fatalities compared to passenger cars. These crashes account for a significant portion of all crash fatalities. Large truck-related crashes in the United States resulted in 5,212 deaths and 114,000 injuries in 2005, with a total of 25,533 fatalities from 2001 to 2005. These crashes also have a significant economic impact, costing society $230.6 billion annually. The Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration's 2006 report found that crashes involving trucks over 10,000 pounds cost $91,112 each, with fatal crashes costing $3,604,518 on average. Investments in advanced safety systems by vehicle suppliers and manufacturers aim to address and reduce commercial vehicle crash scenarios. The Department of Transportation aims to reduce traffic fatalities by implementing advanced safety technologies on commercial motor vehicles to mitigate the societal cost of crashes. Congress aims to increase the deployment of advanced vehicle safety technologies on commercial motor vehicles in the domestic market by providing tax incentives to make these systems more affordable for businesses. The new section SEC. 45O provides a tax credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit under section 38 allows a 50% credit for the cost of qualified systems placed in service, with a limit of $1,500 per system and $3,500 per vehicle. The commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit limits the credit to $3,500 per vehicle, reduced by prior credits, with a maximum of $350,000 per taxpayer for the taxable year. The term 'qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system' refers to property installed on a qualified commercial vehicle as part of a system. The commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit applies to systems like brake stroke monitoring, lane departure warning, collision warning, and vehicle stability systems that enhance safety. The Administrator must identify systems that significantly improve safety or security for qualified commercial vehicles. The commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit applies to certified systems that are appropriate for the qualified commercial vehicle and function as designed when installed properly. The commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit applies to certified systems that are appropriate for the qualified commercial vehicle, installed properly, and functioning as designed. The system must be certified by the installer and depreciation is allowable for the system. The term 'qualified commercial vehicle' refers to any highway motor vehicle used for transporting persons or property in commerce, with a gross weight rating of 26,001 pounds or more, or a seating capacity of at least 15 individuals. The term 'qualified commercial vehicle' includes vehicles with a seating capacity of at least 15 individuals, expected to be used as a school bus or intercity/local bus. A 'brake stroke monitoring system' is defined as an onboard monitoring system. A 'brake stroke monitoring system' uses electronic sensors to detect brake issues and alerts the driver, while a 'lane departure warning system' alerts the driver of unintended lane departure or obstacles. The curr_chunk discusses collision warning systems and vehicle stability systems that help prevent accidents by alerting drivers of potential collision risks and automatically intervening in high-risk situations. The curr_chunk discusses controlled groups for tax purposes, treating related entities as a single taxpayer. In applying section 52 to this section, section 1563 shall be applied without regard to subsection (b)(2)(C). Special rules include basis reduction for property eligible for a credit under subsection (a) and recapture of the credit if the property ceases to be eligible. Property used outside the United States is not qualified for the credit. No credit allowed for property used outside the United States or for property used by tax-exempt entities. Qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety systems not subject to lease have specific rules for credit eligibility. The taxpayer using the property must disclose the credit amount to the entity using it. No credit allowed for qualified commercial vehicles not subject to lease. The taxpayer must provide supporting documentation for the qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system to claim the credit under subsection (a). This documentation must include details about the type of system to be installed on the vehicle. The taxpayer must provide documentation for the qualified commercial vehicle advanced safety system, including details about the system, purchase or installation date, and required certifications under subsection (c)(2) and (c)(3). The section discusses the termination of the commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit for property placed in service after December 31, 2012. It also amends the general business credit section of the Code to include the commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit. The text discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to the commercial vehicle advanced safety system credit. Amendments include changes to sections 1016(a) and 6501(m) of the Code. The amendments made by this section regarding the credit for commercial vehicle advanced safety systems apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
